de.esoco.data.element

Class DataElement<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.property.AbstractStringProperties
      • de.esoco.lib.property.StringProperties
        • de.esoco.data.element.DataElement<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    de.esoco.lib.property.HasProperties, de.esoco.lib.property.MutableProperties, java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BigDecimalDataElement, BooleanDataElement, DataSetDataElement, DateDataElement, IntegerDataElement, ListDataElement, MapDataElement, PeriodDataElement, StringDataElement

    public abstract class DataElement<T>
extends de.esoco.lib.property.StringProperties
    A base class for named data values which can be used to transfer data in serialized form between a server and a client. Data elements can be hierarchical, i.e. a data element can be a child of another data element which must be an instance of DataElementList. The parent of a data element can be queried with the method getParent().
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        Parameters:
        rValue - The value to create the item name for
        Returns:
        The resulting item string (an empty string for a NULL value)

      • getValue

        public abstract T getValue()
        //~ Methods ---------------------------------------------------------------- /*************************************** Returns the value of this element. Each subclass must implement this method separately because some environments (like GWT) require serializable objects to use specific types for serializable fields. Therefore it is not possible to store a generic Object value in the base class.
        Returns:
        The element value

      • copy

        public DataElement<T> copy(DataElement.CopyMode eMode,
                           de.esoco.lib.property.PropertyName<?>... rCopyProperties)
        Returns a copy of this data element that contains all or a subset of it's current state. Always copied are the name and flags. Never copied is the parent reference because upon copying typically a reference to a copied parent needs to be set. The further data the copy contains depends on the copy mode:
        • DataElement.CopyMode.FULL: The copy contains all data (except the parent reference).
        • DataElement.CopyMode.FLAT: like DataElement.CopyMode.FULL but without sub-ordinate data elements.
        • DataElement.CopyMode.PROPERTIES: The copy contains only the properties but not the element value and attributes.
        • DataElement.CopyMode.PLACEHOLDER: The copy contains only the element name to serve as a placeholder.

        The copy instance is created by invoking newInstance() which has the recommendation to overwrite the return type to the concrete subtype to prevent the need for casting by the invoking code. For the same reason it is recommended that subclasses also override this method with the concrete return type and cast the result of super.copy() to that type.

        Parameters:
        eMode - The copy mode
        rCopyProperties - An optional list of properties to copy. If not provided all properties will be copied (unless the mode is DataElement.CopyMode.PLACEHOLDER)
        Returns:
        The copied instance

      • getParent

        public final DataElementList getParent()
        Returns the parent data element list of this element or NULL if it doesn't have a parent. Attention: the parent attribute is transient and will therefore not be restored on deserialization.
        Returns:
        The parent element or NULL for none

      • getPath

        public final java.lang.String getPath()
        Returns the full path of this element in it's hierarchy. The returned path will always start with the PATH_SEPARATOR_CHAR.
        Returns:
        The full element path

      • getResourceId

        public final java.lang.String getResourceId()
        Returns a resource ID string for this element. This ID can be used by user interface code to display a descriptive text for the element value (e.g. as a label). The default implementation first checks for a string property with the type ContentProperties.RESOURCE_ID. If not found it invokes the method createResourceId() which by default returns the capitalized last part of the point-separated element name. Subclasses can override that method to modify the resource ID generation.

        If this instance has a parent data element it prepends the returned resource ID with the parent's child prefix that is returned by the method DataElementList.getChildResourceIdPrefix().

        Returns:
        The resource ID for this element

      • getRoot

        public final DataElementList getRoot()
        Returns the root data element list of this element's hierarchy or NULL if this element doesn't have a parent at all. Attention: the parent attribute is transient and will therefore not be restored on deserialization so that this method will also not return a valid root for deserialized elements.
        Returns:
        The root element or NULL for none

      • getSimpleName

        public final java.lang.String getSimpleName()
        Returns the name of this element without a preceding package.
        Returns:
        The simple data element name

      • isImmutable

        public final boolean isImmutable()
        Returns the immutable state of this element. If this method returns TRUE an invocation of the method setValue(Object) will result in an UnsupportedOperationException being thrown.
        Returns:
        TRUE if this element is immutable, FALSE if the element value can be modified

      • isModified

        public final boolean isModified()
        Returns TRUE if this element's value has been modified.
        Returns:
        TRUE if the element value has changed

      • isOptional

        public final boolean isOptional()
        Returns the immutable state of this element. If this method returns TRUE an invocation of the method setValue(Object) will result in an UnsupportedOperationException being thrown.
        Returns:
        TRUE if this element is immutable, FALSE if the element value can be modified

      • isSelected

        public boolean isSelected()
        Returns the selected state of this element. This attribute will be set for optional data elements depending on the state of the associated option selector in the UI.
        Returns:
        TRUE if this element is selected

      • isValidValue

        public boolean isValidValue(T rValue)
        Checks whether a certain value is valid for this element. A value is considered valid if either this element has no validator, or if the value is NULL and the flag DataElement.Flag.OPTIONAL is set, or if the method Validator.isValid(Object) of this element's validator returns TRUE for the given value. This validation will also be performed by setValue(Object) to throw an exception if a new value is invalid. Therefore applications can use this method to verify values before setting them (e.g. when performing input validation).
        Parameters:
        rValue - The value to check
        Returns:
        TRUE if the value is valid for this data element

      • markAsChanged

        public void markAsChanged()
        Marks this data element as changed.

      • setStringValue

        public void setStringValue(java.lang.String sValue)
        Sets a string value. This method must be overridden by subclasses that want to support the setting of string values in parallel to their native datatype. The default implementation always throws a runtime exception.
        Parameters:
        sValue - The new string value
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If not overridden

        Parameters:
        rNewValue - The new element value
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If this element is read only

        bIncludeProperties - TRUE to include the properties, FALSE to omit

      • newInstance

        protected abstract DataElement<T> newInstance()
        Returns a new instance of the respective data element sub-type on which it is invoked. This is needed for GWT which doesn't support reflection. Used by copy(CopyMode, PropertyName...) for cloning an instance. Implementations should overwrite the return type with their concrete type to prevent the need for casting by the invoking code.
        Returns:
        The new instance

      • updateValue

        protected abstract void updateValue(T rNewValue)
        Updates the element value. Will be invoked by setValue(Object) to store a new value after validation. If a subclass wants to reject certain values it should do so in the isValidValue(Object) method. Subclasses that are always immutable should implement an assertion because if the element has been initialized correctly (validator = NULL) this method should then be reached.
        Parameters:
        rNewValue - The new value for this element

      • checkImmutable

        protected final void checkImmutable()
        Checks whether this instance is read only. Should be invoked by subclasses that contain additional methods to modify attributes to support the read-only state of data elements.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If this element is read only

      • checkValidValue

        protected final void checkValidValue(T rValue)
        Checks whether the given value is valid for this element and throws an exception if not. Invokes isValidValue(Object) to validate the given value.
        Parameters:
        rValue - The value to check
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given value is not valid for this element

      • copyAttributes

        protected void copyAttributes(DataElement<T> rTarget,
                              DataElement.CopyMode eCopyMode)
        Copies the attributes of this instance into another data element of the same type. Subclasses that have additional attributes beside their value should override this method to copy their attributes after invoking super.
        Parameters:
        rTarget - The target to copy the attributes to
        eCopyMode - The copy mode

      • copyValue

        protected void copyValue(DataElement<T> aCopy)
        Copies the value of this data element into another data element of the same type. This is used by the copy(CopyMode, PropertyName...) method and by default uses updateValue(Object) to set the value in the target element. Subclasses that don't support updating the value (e.g. because they manage a collection) need to override this method and implement the copying as needed. They can assume that the target object is of exactly the same type as their own.
        Parameters:
        aCopy - The copied data element to copy the value into

      • createResourceId

        protected java.lang.String createResourceId()
        Creates a resource ID from this data element. This ID will only be created once and is then cached in a transient instance field. See the method getResourceId() for details.
        Returns:
        The resource ID string

      • getValueHashCode

        protected int getValueHashCode()
        Returns the value hash code. Can be overridden by subclasses that have a non-standard internal structure.
        Returns:
        The value hash code

      • hasEqualValueAs

        protected boolean hasEqualValueAs(DataElement<?> rOther)
        Checks whether this element has a value that is equal to that of another element. Can be overridden by subclasses that have a non-standard internal structure.
        Parameters:
        rOther - The other data element which will always be of the same type as this instance
        Returns:
        TRUE if the value are equal

      • valuesEqual

        protected boolean valuesEqual(T a,
                              T b)
        Checks two values for equality. The default implementation invokes the method Object.equals(Object) but subclasses can override this for more specific comparisons (e.g. by using Comparable).
        Parameters:
        a - The first value to compare (can be be NULL)
        b - The second value to compare (can be be NULL)
        Returns:
        TRUE if the values are equal
